video.title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

There&#39;s something strangely meditative about 
watching the process of game studios popping up,

gaining success, expanding, then getting 
shut down for lack of profitability. It&#39;s

like living opposite a sunflower farm being 
tended by a bipolar ex-girlfriend with an

electric carving knife. Still, even I didn&#39;t 
expect that the frequency of studios getting

shut down would lead to some of them trying 
to speedrun it. Take A44 Games, for example,

whose first game was Ashen, a quirky indie 
soulslike that didn&#39;t blow my mind but at

least had some new ideas and a unique visual style 
reminiscent of a post-apocalyptic Playmobil set.

And having established their foot in the door, 
they apparently said &quot;OK, now we&#39;ve got all the

vibrant indie energy out of our system, time 
to start making generically realistic-looking

vaguely AAA aspirant middle of the road guff. 
Flintlock (HURK) Siege of Dawn. Complete

with not only the standard overly optimistic 
franchise-establishing colonized double title,

but a subtitle that abbreviates to SOD. All in 
all, I can only assume A44 Games are called that

because that&#39;s the size of the piece of paper 
you need to write their future prospects on.

It&#39;d be a very small piece of paper, is the joke. 
Yes? Good, I&#39;m glad you came with me on that.

Flintlock Sod is set in an alternative world 
where all progress in fashion and technology

stopped in Napoleonic times because it suddenly 
became terribly important to deal with a horde

of undead that was bleeding into the world 
from Hell. We play a soldier in an army trying

to blow shut the door to the underworld 
once and for all, something goes wrong,

horrors escape into the world, a soulslike ensues. 
The protagonist, whose name you might have noticed

I&#39;m trying to avoid having to say because I&#39;ve 
completely fucking forgotten it and looking it

up might expend vital energy I&#39;m reserving for 
unwrapping the Cadbury&#39;s Eclairs on my desk,

has to team up with one of the supernatural beings 
from the underworld in a severely reduced form to

fuck up all the other supernatural beings making 
trouble across the land. It didn&#39;t escape me that

this dynamic is virtually identical to that of 
the two leads of Forspoken, right down to races,

genders and posh British accents, just with 
the wrist accessory replaced with a cuddly toy.

And what with both games being vaguely open world 
mixed combat traversal-focussed fantasy action

RPGs, I can only assume A44 felt some measures 
were necessary to avoid drawing comparison to

Forspoken, pariah that it is for its quippy 
dialogue marginally less easy on the ears

than a vigorously applied carpenter&#39;s rasp. &quot;I&#39;ve 
got it!&quot; said someone. &quot;Let&#39;s make our two main

characters as boring as possible and get them to 
read out all their lines like they&#39;re discussing

what shade of beige to paint the downstairs loo.&quot; 
&quot;Brilliant! I certainly don&#39;t regret hiring you

from that bus stop outside the dementia hospital.&quot; 
The only thing that passes for chemistry between

whatshername and foxboy is when after every major 
boss fight the boss reveals a damning secret about

foxboy. Oh, turns out he&#39;s to blame for the 
undead horde rising in the first place. Oh,

turns out he&#39;s the god of cream cakes and is 
also to blame for us putting on ten pounds, etc.

Every time it happens the lady gets tokenly 
mad, then foxboy tokenly goes &quot;I&#39;m sowwy I&#39;m

a bad widdle fox&quot; and all enmity is forgotten 
by the time the next scene fades in. You wanna

know how this character arc concludes? So 
the fuck would I. My version of the game

kept crashing whenever I got to the second 
phase of the final boss so I haven&#39;t seen

the ending. But I don&#39;t hold that against it, 
pre-release review copy, these things happen.

The more important takeaway is that on reflection 
I decided I didn&#39;t actually give that much of a

shit. I talk about games that feel thinly 
spread, this is a pat of butter on a piece

of toast the size of a football field. You try 
getting invested in that, it&#39;s like pinning your

wet underpants on a spiderweb. I called the game 
only &quot;vaguely&quot; open world &#39;cos the environments

are laid out in a linear sequence but they spread 
out a bit so a few sidequests can be squeezed in,

although I didn&#39;t bother with most of them 
and wasn&#39;t the least bit underpowered so

the game&#39;s only open world in the sense that 
a snickers in some lettuce is technically a

nutritionally balanced meal. And you can go 
back and forth to previously completed areas

as much as you want if you&#39;re incredibly 
bored and want to make yourself even more

bored in order to break your personal record. 
But apparently not everyone on the design team

was entirely clear on the open world elements 
- you&#39;ve got a couple of double jumps in your

moveset to help expand your verticality and I was 
traversing the rooftops of a little town area,

made it all the way to what seemed very much like 
the next plot important door, but it wouldn&#39;t open

and nothing happened. Because it turned out 
the door didn&#39;t open until I backtracked to

the centre of town and stood in a specific spot so 
my character could say &quot;Oh look, we&#39;re in a town.&quot;

Like a slalom skier with injured testicles, the 
designers seem to have had a flag problem. It&#39;s

definitely got a lack of focus problem, as 
does the combat. You&#39;ve got a melee attack,

you&#39;ve got guns. Flintlock guns, naturally, it&#39;s 
not called Browning Semi-Automatic The Siege of

Dawn. You use the guns to do Bloodborne-style 
interrupts of unblockable enemy attacks,

but the parrying you do with your melee weapon 
in a substantially less Bloodborne-y kind of way.

And either there&#39;s something weird going on with 
the parry or me and my left index finger are going

to have to see a relationship counsellor, &#39;cos I 
swear it only worked about half the time whether

or not I hit the window. Could be the slight 
jitteriness of the enemy animations making them

harder to read, could be the way the enemies blend 
into the visual noise of the generic environments,

could be the Mafia frightener behind my sofa who 
keeps smacking me in the head when he thinks I&#39;m

not paying attention, whatever the case, 
the combat just never felt right. And yet,

I also never ran into much in the way of 
difficulty walls. Turns out the gunshot being a

reliable interrupt of virtually every enemy attack 
doesn&#39;t give them much of a chance. Sure, you need

to land four melee attacks to reload a bullet, 
but come on, you can&#39;t melee the guy four times?

He&#39;s there, you&#39;ve got a whacking stick, what 
else are you gonna do, challenge him to snooker?

All of this, the iffiness of the world design, 
the whiffiness of the combat mechanics,

smacks of a game that chose too large and 
tumescent a willy than its poor little gag

reflex could handle. It needed to pick one or 
two big toilet bowls to focus on rather than

try to get a little bit of urine into a hundred 
little cups. I didn&#39;t even mention the whole magic

mechanic in combat where you instruct your fox 
pal to nibble the enemy&#39;s bum to build up a bar

so that in some glorious distant future we might 
aspire to doing a special attack that isn&#39;t much

better than all your other shit. Or the fucking 
gamelong side minigame thing that means every

other character you meet is really into collecting 
pogs. In short, Bollock Sod loaded down its buffet

plate too much. And I know it did because the 
game feels distinctly shortened, like it had to

be cut down when deadlines loomed. There&#39;s only, 
like, four unique boss fights and one of them gets

awkwardly crowbarred into the middle of someone 
else&#39;s chapter because the plot had hyped them up

and they needed to be somewhere. The lesson is, 
ambition is like riding a big horse. It makes

you feel powerful but in the wrong place it&#39;s 
really going to annoy the carpet cleaning service.
